Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
More than 2,500 years ago, one of ancient Greece’s most celebrated 
popstars and erotic poets enraptured listeners. In one legend, a prominent Athenian heard
his nephew singing one of their songs and enjoyed it so much that he asked 
the boy to teach it to him— “So that I may learn it and die,” he said. So, who was this revered figure? Her name was Sappho. She lived on the Greek island 
of Lesbos around 600 BCE. Like other singer-songwriters of the time, she sang while playing the lyre, a stringed instrument from which
the term “lyrics” is derived. But Sappho lyrics offered a uniquely
intimate perspective on love, passion, and longing. She’s the first on record to combine the 
words “bitter” and “sweet,” for instance, to describe at once the thrills 
and devastations of romance. Sappho was an aristocrat thought
to have married a man, though none of her surviving
work mentions him. It does reference other family
as well as festivals, colorful clothing, and growing old. But Sappho is best known for her lyrics
about homoerotic desire for women. In one song, as her female companion
departs tearfully, Sappho says, “let me remind you /
... the lovely times we shared.” She describes flower garlands, perfumes,
“and,” she says, “on soft beds / 
... you quenched your desire.” In another, she describes 
a friend in a distant city, “Pacing far away, her gentle heart
devoured by powerful desire, she remembers slender Atthis.” The word “Lesbian” means 
someone from Lesbos, but, because of Sappho, 
it now also describes a woman who’s gay. In ancient Greece, the norm was 
for everyone to marry and have children. While men were usually permitted to have
homosexual relationships based on their status, 
women weren’t. But it appears that, 
on Lesbos at this time, aristocratic women generally
had more freedom. Yet the details of Sappho’s
life remain mysterious, partially because only fragments 
of her poetry survive. In ancient times, however, 
so much of it persisted that it seemed it would last forever. Admirers performed Sappho cover songs
and committed her poetry to papyrus, parchment, and pottery. Three centuries after Sappho’s death, a Greek author declared that her words
would endure “as long as ships sail from the Nile.” Another century later, the Library of  Alexandria housed 
nine scrolls of her work, numbering over 10,000 lines. But natural forces eroded the collection. And monks, tasked with preserving 
ancient writing, likely neglected or destroyed her work. One 2nd century Christian leader 
called Sappho “a whore who sang about her
own licentiousness.” Later, a Pope and Archbishop
ordered her poetry burned. Almost all of it had vanished
by the Middle Ages. Then, about a century ago, people began rediscovering 
Sappho’s poetry— in locations like an ancient Egyptian 
garbage dump. Now, we have around 700 lines, representing less than 10%
of Sappho’s total known work. We only have one complete poem of hers. About a dozen others are substantial,
but most are mere fragments. New pieces of Sappho’s songs 
probably will be found. Some may already be sitting 
in museum archives, to be revealed when technology 
allows scholars to read through scrolls 
too fragile to unroll. What we are currently left 
with is an incomplete record— and many historical rumors. Ovid insisted that Sappho fell 
in love with a ferryman and, upon being rejected,
leapt from a cliff to her death. Another tale asserts that she ran 
a girls’ school and those mentioned in her poems
were merely students for whom she felt platonic affection. Current consensus is that these stories, which ridicule Sappho 
or deny her work’s homoeroticism, are probably all untrue artifacts
of misogyny and homophobia. Despite the distortions 
of the intervening millennia, Sappho’s words reach across time
and resonate today. More than 2,000 years ago, she wrote: “I say someone in another time 
will remember us” And, thankfully, we do.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Sappho lived in:
Options: A. Athens, B. Ithaca, C. Lesbos, D. Santorini
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the ancient Greek poet known for her lyrics about love, passion, and longing? Options: A. Socrates, B. Homer, C. Sappho, D. Euripides Correct Option: C
Question 2: What instrument did Sappho play while singing her songs? Options: A. Harp, B. Lyre, C. Flute, D. Drums Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the origin of the term "lyrics" in relation to music? Options: A. From the Greek word for "song", B. From the name of a famous poet, C. From the instrument "lyre", D. From the Latin word for "music" Correct Option: C
Question 4: How did Sappho's poetry challenge the social norms of ancient Greece? Options: A. By promoting the idea of marriage and children, B. By depicting homoerotic desire between women, C. By glorifying war and violence, D. By advocating for the rights of slaves Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the significance of the Library of Alexandria in relation to Sappho's work? Options: A. It was where Sappho wrote most of her poetry, B. It was where her poetry was first performed, C. It housed nine scrolls of her work, numbering over 10,000 lines, D. It was where her poetry was banned Correct Option: C
Question 6: Why did Sappho's poetry almost disappear by the Middle Ages? Options: A. Due to natural disasters and erosion, B. Because monks and Christian leaders deliberately destroyed or neglected her work, C. Due to a lack of interest in her poetry, D. Because it was considered too explicit Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did the term "Lesbian" come to be associated with a woman who is gay? Options: A. Because Sappho was from the island of Lesbos and wrote about homoerotic desire, B. Because the term was coined by a modern LGBTQ+ activist, C. Because it was a derogatory term used to describe women who loved women, D. Because it was a term used to describe a type of poetry Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the current consensus among scholars about the stories surrounding Sappho's life? Options: A. That they are mostly true and based on historical evidence, B. That they are probably all untrue artifacts of misogyny and homophobia, C. That they are a mix of fact and fiction, D. That they are irrelevant to understanding her poetry Correct Option: B
Question 9: How do Sappho's words continue to resonate with people today, despite being written over 2,000 years ago? Options: A. Because they deal with universal themes of love and desire, B. Because they are a product of their time and no longer relevant, C. Because they are a reflection of the cultural norms of ancient Greece, D. Because they are a curiosity of historical significance only Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the significance of Sappho's statement "I say someone in another time will remember us"? Options: A. It is a prediction of her own fame and success, B. It is a reflection of her desire for immortality, C. It is a statement of hope that her words will transcend time and be remembered, D. It is a commentary on the fleeting nature of human life Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 1 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

However, since Question 1 does not ask about Sappho's place of residence, I will look for other options that might match the ground truth MCQ more closely.

Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs directly ask about Sappho's place of residence. But if I had to choose one that is remotely related to the ground truth MCQ, I would choose Question 7, which mentions the island of Lesbos.

So, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is: 7

Please note that this is not an exact match, and the generated MCQs do not directly address the question of Sappho's place of residence.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
More than 2,500 years ago, one of ancient Greece’s most celebrated 
popstars and erotic poets enraptured listeners. In one legend, a prominent Athenian heard
his nephew singing one of their songs and enjoyed it so much that he asked 
the boy to teach it to him— “So that I may learn it and die,” he said. So, who was this revered figure? Her name was Sappho. She lived on the Greek island 
of Lesbos around 600 BCE. Like other singer-songwriters of the time, she sang while playing the lyre, a stringed instrument from which
the term “lyrics” is derived. But Sappho lyrics offered a uniquely
intimate perspective on love, passion, and longing. She’s the first on record to combine the 
words “bitter” and “sweet,” for instance, to describe at once the thrills 
and devastations of romance. Sappho was an aristocrat thought
to have married a man, though none of her surviving
work mentions him. It does reference other family
as well as festivals, colorful clothing, and growing old. But Sappho is best known for her lyrics
about homoerotic desire for women. In one song, as her female companion
departs tearfully, Sappho says, “let me remind you /
... the lovely times we shared.” She describes flower garlands, perfumes,
“and,” she says, “on soft beds / 
... you quenched your desire.” In another, she describes 
a friend in a distant city, “Pacing far away, her gentle heart
devoured by powerful desire, she remembers slender Atthis.” The word “Lesbian” means 
someone from Lesbos, but, because of Sappho, 
it now also describes a woman who’s gay. In ancient Greece, the norm was 
for everyone to marry and have children. While men were usually permitted to have
homosexual relationships based on their status, 
women weren’t. But it appears that, 
on Lesbos at this time, aristocratic women generally
had more freedom. Yet the details of Sappho’s
life remain mysterious, partially because only fragments 
of her poetry survive. In ancient times, however, 
so much of it persisted that it seemed it would last forever. Admirers performed Sappho cover songs
and committed her poetry to papyrus, parchment, and pottery. Three centuries after Sappho’s death, a Greek author declared that her words
would endure “as long as ships sail from the Nile.” Another century later, the Library of  Alexandria housed 
nine scrolls of her work, numbering over 10,000 lines. But natural forces eroded the collection. And monks, tasked with preserving 
ancient writing, likely neglected or destroyed her work. One 2nd century Christian leader 
called Sappho “a whore who sang about her
own licentiousness.” Later, a Pope and Archbishop
ordered her poetry burned. Almost all of it had vanished
by the Middle Ages. Then, about a century ago, people began rediscovering 
Sappho’s poetry— in locations like an ancient Egyptian 
garbage dump. Now, we have around 700 lines, representing less than 10%
of Sappho’s total known work. We only have one complete poem of hers. About a dozen others are substantial,
but most are mere fragments. New pieces of Sappho’s songs 
probably will be found. Some may already be sitting 
in museum archives, to be revealed when technology 
allows scholars to read through scrolls 
too fragile to unroll. What we are currently left 
with is an incomplete record— and many historical rumors. Ovid insisted that Sappho fell 
in love with a ferryman and, upon being rejected,
leapt from a cliff to her death. Another tale asserts that she ran 
a girls’ school and those mentioned in her poems
were merely students for whom she felt platonic affection. Current consensus is that these stories, which ridicule Sappho 
or deny her work’s homoeroticism, are probably all untrue artifacts
of misogyny and homophobia. Despite the distortions 
of the intervening millennia, Sappho’s words reach across time
and resonate today. More than 2,000 years ago, she wrote: “I say someone in another time 
will remember us” And, thankfully, we do.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Sappho performed her songs with which instrument?
Options: A. flute, B. harp, C. lute, D. lyre
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the ancient Greek poet known for her lyrics about love, passion, and longing? Options: A. Socrates, B. Homer, C. Sappho, D. Euripides Correct Option: C
Question 2: What instrument did Sappho play while singing her songs? Options: A. Harp, B. Lyre, C. Flute, D. Drums Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the origin of the term "lyrics" in relation to music? Options: A. From the Greek word for "song", B. From the name of a famous poet, C. From the instrument "lyre", D. From the Latin word for "music" Correct Option: C
Question 4: How did Sappho's poetry challenge the social norms of ancient Greece? Options: A. By promoting the idea of marriage and children, B. By depicting homoerotic desire between women, C. By glorifying war and violence, D. By advocating for the rights of slaves Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the significance of the Library of Alexandria in relation to Sappho's work? Options: A. It was where Sappho wrote most of her poetry, B. It was where her poetry was first performed, C. It housed nine scrolls of her work, numbering over 10,000 lines, D. It was where her poetry was banned Correct Option: C
Question 6: Why did Sappho's poetry almost disappear by the Middle Ages? Options: A. Due to natural disasters and erosion, B. Because monks and Christian leaders deliberately destroyed or neglected her work, C. Due to a lack of interest in her poetry, D. Because it was considered too explicit Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did the term "Lesbian" come to be associated with a woman who is gay? Options: A. Because Sappho was from the island of Lesbos and wrote about homoerotic desire, B. Because the term was coined by a modern LGBTQ+ activist, C. Because it was a derogatory term used to describe women who loved women, D. Because it was a term used to describe a type of poetry Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the current consensus among scholars about the stories surrounding Sappho's life? Options: A. That they are mostly true and based on historical evidence, B. That they are probably all untrue artifacts of misogyny and homophobia, C. That they are a mix of fact and fiction, D. That they are irrelevant to understanding her poetry Correct Option: B
Question 9: How do Sappho's words continue to resonate with people today, despite being written over 2,000 years ago? Options: A. Because they deal with universal themes of love and desire, B. Because they are a product of their time and no longer relevant, C. Because they are a reflection of the cultural norms of ancient Greece, D. Because they are a curiosity of historical significance only Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the significance of Sappho's statement "I say someone in another time will remember us"? Options: A. It is a prediction of her own fame and success, B. It is a reflection of her desire for immortality, C. It is a statement of hope that her words will transcend time and be remembered, D. It is a commentary on the fleeting nature of human life Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 2: What instrument did Sappho play while singing her songs? Options: A. Harp, B. Lyre, C. Flute, D. Drums Correct Option: B**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the instrument Sappho played, and both have the correct answer as the lyre.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: **2**

**Transcript**:
More than 2,500 years ago, one of ancient Greece’s most celebrated 
popstars and erotic poets enraptured listeners. In one legend, a prominent Athenian heard
his nephew singing one of their songs and enjoyed it so much that he asked 
the boy to teach it to him— “So that I may learn it and die,” he said. So, who was this revered figure? Her name was Sappho. She lived on the Greek island 
of Lesbos around 600 BCE. Like other singer-songwriters of the time, she sang while playing the lyre, a stringed instrument from which
the term “lyrics” is derived. But Sappho lyrics offered a uniquely
intimate perspective on love, passion, and longing. She’s the first on record to combine the 
words “bitter” and “sweet,” for instance, to describe at once the thrills 
and devastations of romance. Sappho was an aristocrat thought
to have married a man, though none of her surviving
work mentions him. It does reference other family
as well as festivals, colorful clothing, and growing old. But Sappho is best known for her lyrics
about homoerotic desire for women. In one song, as her female companion
departs tearfully, Sappho says, “let me remind you /
... the lovely times we shared.” She describes flower garlands, perfumes,
“and,” she says, “on soft beds / 
... you quenched your desire.” In another, she describes 
a friend in a distant city, “Pacing far away, her gentle heart
devoured by powerful desire, she remembers slender Atthis.” The word “Lesbian” means 
someone from Lesbos, but, because of Sappho, 
it now also describes a woman who’s gay. In ancient Greece, the norm was 
for everyone to marry and have children. While men were usually permitted to have
homosexual relationships based on their status, 
women weren’t. But it appears that, 
on Lesbos at this time, aristocratic women generally
had more freedom. Yet the details of Sappho’s
life remain mysterious, partially because only fragments 
of her poetry survive. In ancient times, however, 
so much of it persisted that it seemed it would last forever. Admirers performed Sappho cover songs
and committed her poetry to papyrus, parchment, and pottery. Three centuries after Sappho’s death, a Greek author declared that her words
would endure “as long as ships sail from the Nile.” Another century later, the Library of  Alexandria housed 
nine scrolls of her work, numbering over 10,000 lines. But natural forces eroded the collection. And monks, tasked with preserving 
ancient writing, likely neglected or destroyed her work. One 2nd century Christian leader 
called Sappho “a whore who sang about her
own licentiousness.” Later, a Pope and Archbishop
ordered her poetry burned. Almost all of it had vanished
by the Middle Ages. Then, about a century ago, people began rediscovering 
Sappho’s poetry— in locations like an ancient Egyptian 
garbage dump. Now, we have around 700 lines, representing less than 10%
of Sappho’s total known work. We only have one complete poem of hers. About a dozen others are substantial,
but most are mere fragments. New pieces of Sappho’s songs 
probably will be found. Some may already be sitting 
in museum archives, to be revealed when technology 
allows scholars to read through scrolls 
too fragile to unroll. What we are currently left 
with is an incomplete record— and many historical rumors. Ovid insisted that Sappho fell 
in love with a ferryman and, upon being rejected,
leapt from a cliff to her death. Another tale asserts that she ran 
a girls’ school and those mentioned in her poems
were merely students for whom she felt platonic affection. Current consensus is that these stories, which ridicule Sappho 
or deny her work’s homoeroticism, are probably all untrue artifacts
of misogyny and homophobia. Despite the distortions 
of the intervening millennia, Sappho’s words reach across time
and resonate today. More than 2,000 years ago, she wrote: “I say someone in another time 
will remember us” And, thankfully, we do.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. men, B. women, C. nature, D. the gods
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
More than 2,500 years ago, one of ancient Greece’s most celebrated 
popstars and erotic poets enraptured listeners. In one legend, a prominent Athenian heard
his nephew singing one of their songs and enjoyed it so much that he asked 
the boy to teach it to him— “So that I may learn it and die,” he said. So, who was this revered figure? Her name was Sappho. She lived on the Greek island 
of Lesbos around 600 BCE. Like other singer-songwriters of the time, she sang while playing the lyre, a stringed instrument from which
the term “lyrics” is derived. But Sappho lyrics offered a uniquely
intimate perspective on love, passion, and longing. She’s the first on record to combine the 
words “bitter” and “sweet,” for instance, to describe at once the thrills 
and devastations of romance. Sappho was an aristocrat thought
to have married a man, though none of her surviving
work mentions him. It does reference other family
as well as festivals, colorful clothing, and growing old. But Sappho is best known for her lyrics
about homoerotic desire for women. In one song, as her female companion
departs tearfully, Sappho says, “let me remind you /
... the lovely times we shared.” She describes flower garlands, perfumes,
“and,” she says, “on soft beds / 
... you quenched your desire.” In another, she describes 
a friend in a distant city, “Pacing far away, her gentle heart
devoured by powerful desire, she remembers slender Atthis.” The word “Lesbian” means 
someone from Lesbos, but, because of Sappho, 
it now also describes a woman who’s gay. In ancient Greece, the norm was 
for everyone to marry and have children. While men were usually permitted to have
homosexual relationships based on their status, 
women weren’t. But it appears that, 
on Lesbos at this time, aristocratic women generally
had more freedom. Yet the details of Sappho’s
life remain mysterious, partially because only fragments 
of her poetry survive. In ancient times, however, 
so much of it persisted that it seemed it would last forever. Admirers performed Sappho cover songs
and committed her poetry to papyrus, parchment, and pottery. Three centuries after Sappho’s death, a Greek author declared that her words
would endure “as long as ships sail from the Nile.” Another century later, the Library of  Alexandria housed 
nine scrolls of her work, numbering over 10,000 lines. But natural forces eroded the collection. And monks, tasked with preserving 
ancient writing, likely neglected or destroyed her work. One 2nd century Christian leader 
called Sappho “a whore who sang about her
own licentiousness.” Later, a Pope and Archbishop
ordered her poetry burned. Almost all of it had vanished
by the Middle Ages. Then, about a century ago, people began rediscovering 
Sappho’s poetry— in locations like an ancient Egyptian 
garbage dump. Now, we have around 700 lines, representing less than 10%
of Sappho’s total known work. We only have one complete poem of hers. About a dozen others are substantial,
but most are mere fragments. New pieces of Sappho’s songs 
probably will be found. Some may already be sitting 
in museum archives, to be revealed when technology 
allows scholars to read through scrolls 
too fragile to unroll. What we are currently left 
with is an incomplete record— and many historical rumors. Ovid insisted that Sappho fell 
in love with a ferryman and, upon being rejected,
leapt from a cliff to her death. Another tale asserts that she ran 
a girls’ school and those mentioned in her poems
were merely students for whom she felt platonic affection. Current consensus is that these stories, which ridicule Sappho 
or deny her work’s homoeroticism, are probably all untrue artifacts
of misogyny and homophobia. Despite the distortions 
of the intervening millennia, Sappho’s words reach across time
and resonate today. More than 2,000 years ago, she wrote: “I say someone in another time 
will remember us” And, thankfully, we do.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Of the nine scrolls of Sappho’s poetry collected in the Library of Alexandria in antiquity, about what percent survives today?
Options: A. less than 10, B. 50, C. 25, D. 75
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the ancient Greek poet known for her lyrics about love, passion, and longing? Options: A. Socrates, B. Homer, C. Sappho, D. Euripides Correct Option: C
Question 2: What instrument did Sappho play while singing her songs? Options: A. Harp, B. Lyre, C. Flute, D. Drums Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the origin of the term "lyrics" in relation to music? Options: A. From the Greek word for "song", B. From the name of a famous poet, C. From the instrument "lyre", D. From the Latin word for "music" Correct Option: C
Question 4: How did Sappho's poetry challenge the social norms of ancient Greece? Options: A. By promoting the idea of marriage and children, B. By depicting homoerotic desire between women, C. By glorifying war and violence, D. By advocating for the rights of slaves Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the significance of the Library of Alexandria in relation to Sappho's work? Options: A. It was where Sappho wrote most of her poetry, B. It was where her poetry was first performed, C. It housed nine scrolls of her work, numbering over 10,000 lines, D. It was where her poetry was banned Correct Option: C
Question 6: Why did Sappho's poetry almost disappear by the Middle Ages? Options: A. Due to natural disasters and erosion, B. Because monks and Christian leaders deliberately destroyed or neglected her work, C. Due to a lack of interest in her poetry, D. Because it was considered too explicit Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did the term "Lesbian" come to be associated with a woman who is gay? Options: A. Because Sappho was from the island of Lesbos and wrote about homoerotic desire, B. Because the term was coined by a modern LGBTQ+ activist, C. Because it was a derogatory term used to describe women who loved women, D. Because it was a term used to describe a type of poetry Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the current consensus among scholars about the stories surrounding Sappho's life? Options: A. That they are mostly true and based on historical evidence, B. That they are probably all untrue artifacts of misogyny and homophobia, C. That they are a mix of fact and fiction, D. That they are irrelevant to understanding her poetry Correct Option: B
Question 9: How do Sappho's words continue to resonate with people today, despite being written over 2,000 years ago? Options: A. Because they deal with universal themes of love and desire, B. Because they are a product of their time and no longer relevant, C. Because they are a reflection of the cultural norms of ancient Greece, D. Because they are a curiosity of historical significance only Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the significance of Sappho's statement "I say someone in another time will remember us"? Options: A. It is a prediction of her own fame and success, B. It is a reflection of her desire for immortality, C. It is a statement of hope that her words will transcend time and be remembered, D. It is a commentary on the fleeting nature of human life Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

But, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that could be modified to match the ground truth MCQ, I would choose Question 5, as it mentions the Library of Alexandria and the number of scrolls of Sappho's work.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
More than 2,500 years ago, one of ancient Greece’s most celebrated 
popstars and erotic poets enraptured listeners. In one legend, a prominent Athenian heard
his nephew singing one of their songs and enjoyed it so much that he asked 
the boy to teach it to him— “So that I may learn it and die,” he said. So, who was this revered figure? Her name was Sappho. She lived on the Greek island 
of Lesbos around 600 BCE. Like other singer-songwriters of the time, she sang while playing the lyre, a stringed instrument from which
the term “lyrics” is derived. But Sappho lyrics offered a uniquely
intimate perspective on love, passion, and longing. She’s the first on record to combine the 
words “bitter” and “sweet,” for instance, to describe at once the thrills 
and devastations of romance. Sappho was an aristocrat thought
to have married a man, though none of her surviving
work mentions him. It does reference other family
as well as festivals, colorful clothing, and growing old. But Sappho is best known for her lyrics
about homoerotic desire for women. In one song, as her female companion
departs tearfully, Sappho says, “let me remind you /
... the lovely times we shared.” She describes flower garlands, perfumes,
“and,” she says, “on soft beds / 
... you quenched your desire.” In another, she describes 
a friend in a distant city, “Pacing far away, her gentle heart
devoured by powerful desire, she remembers slender Atthis.” The word “Lesbian” means 
someone from Lesbos, but, because of Sappho, 
it now also describes a woman who’s gay. In ancient Greece, the norm was 
for everyone to marry and have children. While men were usually permitted to have
homosexual relationships based on their status, 
women weren’t. But it appears that, 
on Lesbos at this time, aristocratic women generally
had more freedom. Yet the details of Sappho’s
life remain mysterious, partially because only fragments 
of her poetry survive. In ancient times, however, 
so much of it persisted that it seemed it would last forever. Admirers performed Sappho cover songs
and committed her poetry to papyrus, parchment, and pottery. Three centuries after Sappho’s death, a Greek author declared that her words
would endure “as long as ships sail from the Nile.” Another century later, the Library of  Alexandria housed 
nine scrolls of her work, numbering over 10,000 lines. But natural forces eroded the collection. And monks, tasked with preserving 
ancient writing, likely neglected or destroyed her work. One 2nd century Christian leader 
called Sappho “a whore who sang about her
own licentiousness.” Later, a Pope and Archbishop
ordered her poetry burned. Almost all of it had vanished
by the Middle Ages. Then, about a century ago, people began rediscovering 
Sappho’s poetry— in locations like an ancient Egyptian 
garbage dump. Now, we have around 700 lines, representing less than 10%
of Sappho’s total known work. We only have one complete poem of hers. About a dozen others are substantial,
but most are mere fragments. New pieces of Sappho’s songs 
probably will be found. Some may already be sitting 
in museum archives, to be revealed when technology 
allows scholars to read through scrolls 
too fragile to unroll. What we are currently left 
with is an incomplete record— and many historical rumors. Ovid insisted that Sappho fell 
in love with a ferryman and, upon being rejected,
leapt from a cliff to her death. Another tale asserts that she ran 
a girls’ school and those mentioned in her poems
were merely students for whom she felt platonic affection. Current consensus is that these stories, which ridicule Sappho 
or deny her work’s homoeroticism, are probably all untrue artifacts
of misogyny and homophobia. Despite the distortions 
of the intervening millennia, Sappho’s words reach across time
and resonate today. More than 2,000 years ago, she wrote: “I say someone in another time 
will remember us” And, thankfully, we do.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fragments of Sappho’s poetry from antiquity are written on or in which of the following?
Options: A. handbooks, B. papyrus, C. parchment, D. pottery, E. all of the above
Correct Option: E

Question 3: What is the origin of the term "lyrics" in relation to music? Options: A. From the Greek word for "song", B. From the name of a famous poet, C. From the instrument "lyre", D. From the Latin word for "music" Correct Option: C
Question 4: How did Sappho's poetry challenge the social norms of ancient Greece? Options: A. By promoting the idea of marriage and children, B. By depicting homoerotic desire between women, C. By glorifying war and violence, D. By advocating for the rights of slaves Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the significance of the Library of Alexandria in relation to Sappho's work? Options: A. It was where Sappho wrote most of her poetry, B. It was where her poetry was first performed, C. It housed nine scrolls of her work, numbering over 10,000 lines, D. It was where her poetry was banned Correct Option: C
Question 6: Why did Sappho's poetry almost disappear by the Middle Ages? Options: A. Due to natural disasters and erosion, B. Because monks and Christian leaders deliberately destroyed or neglected her work, C. Due to a lack of interest in her poetry, D. Because it was considered too explicit Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did the term "Lesbian" come to be associated with a woman who is gay? Options: A. Because Sappho was from the island of Lesbos and wrote about homoerotic desire, B. Because the term was coined by a modern LGBTQ+ activist, C. Because it was a derogatory term used to describe women who loved women, D. Because it was a term used to describe a type of poetry Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the current consensus among scholars about the stories surrounding Sappho's life? Options: A. That they are mostly true and based on historical evidence, B. That they are probably all untrue artifacts of misogyny and homophobia, C. That they are a mix of fact and fiction, D. That they are irrelevant to understanding her poetry Correct Option: B
Question 9: How do Sappho's words continue to resonate with people today, despite being written over 2,000 years ago? Options: A. Because they deal with universal themes of love and desire, B. Because they are a product of their time and no longer relevant, C. Because they are a reflection of the cultural norms of ancient Greece, D. Because they are a curiosity of historical significance only Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the significance of Sappho's statement "I say someone in another time will remember us"? Options: A. It is a prediction of her own fame and success, B. It is a reflection of her desire for immortality, C. It is a statement of hope that her words will transcend time and be remembered, D. Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 5 is the closest in terms of content and intent.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the materials on which fragments of Sappho's poetry from antiquity are written, while Question 5 asks about the significance of the Library of Alexandria in relation to Sappho's work. Although not identical, Question 5 does mention that the Library of Alexandria "housed nine scrolls of her work, numbering over 10,000 lines", which implies that Sappho's poetry was written on scrolls, which is related to the options in the ground truth MCQ (papyrus, parchment, pottery).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1960, American composer John Cage 
went on national television to share his latest work. But rather than employing
traditional instruments, Cage appeared surrounded 
by household clutter, including a bathtub, ice cubes,
a toy fish, a pressure cooker, a rubber duck, and several radios. Armed with these tools and a stopwatch,
he performed “Water Walk,” setting off a series of sounds
with a serious expression and incredible precision. Some viewers found
the performance hysterical, while others thought it was
completely absurd. But most people watching likely shared 
the same question: is this even music? This question is harder to answer
than you might think. What we determine as music often
depends on our expectations. For example, imagine you’re 
in a jazz club listening to the rhythmic honking of horns. Most people would agree
that this is music. But if you were on the highway hearing
the same thing, many would call it noise. After all, car horns aren’t instruments and these drivers aren’t 
musicians... right? Expectations like these influence how
we categorize everything we hear. We typically think something sounds 
more musical if it uses a recognizable structure 
or popular sounds arranged in well-known patterns. And even within the realm of music, we expect certain genres to use specific
instruments and harmonies. These expectations are based 
on existing musical traditions, but those traditions aren't set in stone. They vary across different cultures
and time periods. And in the early 20th century, when many artists were pushing 
the boundaries of their fields, John Cage wanted to discover 
what new kinds of music might exist beyond those constraints. He began pioneering new instruments
that blurred the lines between art and everyday life, and used surprising objects to reinvent
existing instruments. He also explored new ways for music
to mingle with other art forms. He and his creative and romantic partner,
Merce Cunningham, held recitals where Cage’s music
and Cunningham’s choreography would be created independently
before being performed together. But whatever his approach, Cage gleefully dared listeners to question
the boundaries between music and noise, as well as sound and silence. Perhaps the best example is one of Cage’s
most famous compositions— a solo piano piece consisting of nothing
but musical rests for four minutes and 33 seconds. This wasn’t intended as a prank,
but rather, as a question. Could the opening and closing
of a piano lid be music? What about the click of a stopwatch? The rustling, and perhaps even the
complaining, of a crowd? Like the white canvases
of his painting peers, Cage asked the audience to question 
their expectations about what music was. And while the piece didn’t evoke the drama
of some traditional compositions, it certainly elicited a strong
emotional response. Cage’s work frequently prioritized
these spontaneous, ephemeral experiences over precise, predictable performances. He even developed processes that left some
compositional decisions up to chance. One of his favorite such systems
was the I Ching, an ancient Chinese divination text. Using just a handful of coins, the I Ching allows readers 
to produce a pattern of lines which can be interpreted
to answer questions and offer fortunes. But Cage adapted these patterns
into a series of tables that generated different musical 
durations, tempos, and dynamics. Eventually, he even used early computers
to help produce these random parameters. For some pieces, Cage went even further, offering musicians incomplete compositions
notated with broad instructions, allowing them to compose on the fly
with the help of his guidelines. Some composers rejected Cage's
seemingly careless approach. They believed it was the composer’s job 
to organize sound and time for a specific, intentional purpose. After all, if these strange compositions 
were music, then where do we draw the line? But like a bold explorer, Cage didn't
want to be bound by restrictions, and he certainly didn't want
to follow old rules. He dedicated himself to shattering
our expectations, creating a series
of once in a lifetime experiences that continue encouraging 
musicians and audiences to embrace the unexpected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following “instruments” was used for the piece Water Walk?
Options: A. A theremin, B. A rubber duck, C. A tuba, D. A cello
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who performed "Water Walk" on national television in 1960, using unconventional instruments like a bathtub and a rubber duck? Options: A. Merce Cunningham, B. John Cage, C. Charlie Parker, D. Thelonious Monk Correct Option: B
Question 2: What determines whether we perceive a sound as music or noise, according to the transcript? Options: A. The instrument used to produce the sound, B. The context in which we hear the sound, C. The volume of the sound, D. The duration of the sound Correct Option: B
Question 3: Imagine you are a music teacher, and you want to encourage your students to think creatively about what constitutes music. Which of the following activities would align with John Cage's approach? Options: A. Asking students to compose a traditional symphony, B. Encouraging students to experiment with unconventional instruments, C. Teaching students to play a famous jazz solo, D. Having students practice playing in perfect harmony Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the purpose of John Cage's composition consisting of four minutes and 33 seconds of silence? Options: A. To create a sense of calm in the audience, B. To challenge the audience's expectations about what music is, C. To showcase the pianist's technical skill, D. To make a statement about the importance of silence Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did John Cage use the I Ching in his compositional process? Options: A. As a source of inspiration for his melodies, B. As a way to generate random musical parameters, C. As a guide for selecting instruments, D. As a means of communicating with his collaborators Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was a key aspect of John Cage's approach to music composition? Options: A. Emphasis on traditional harmony and structure, B. Use of chance and indeterminacy, C. Focus on creating complex, intricate melodies, D. Prioritization of technical virtuosity Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did John Cage's work with Merce Cunningham reflect his interest in blurring the lines between art forms? Options: A. They collaborated on a series of paintings, B. They created music and dance pieces independently, then performed them together, C. They wrote a joint manifesto on the importance of interdisciplinary art, D. They founded a school for interdisciplinary arts Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was a common criticism of John Cage's compositional approach? Options: A. That it was too rigid and structured, B. That it was too focused on traditional instruments, C. That it was too careless and lacking in intention, D. That it was too complex and difficult to understand Correct Option: C
Question 9: How did John Cage's use of everyday objects as instruments reflect his artistic goals? Options: A. It was a way to showcase his technical skill as a musician, B. It was a means of creating complex, intricate sounds, C. It was a way to challenge the audience's expectations about what music is, D. It was a way to pay homage to traditional musical instruments Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is a key legacy of John Cage's work, according to the transcript? Options: A. A renewed emphasis on traditional musical structures, B. A greater appreciation for the importance of technical virtuosity, C. A continued encouragement of musicians and audiences to embrace the unexpected, D. A clearer definition of what constitutes "music" Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although Question 1 does not directly ask about the "instruments" used for the piece Water Walk, it does mention "unconventional instruments like a bathtub and a rubber duck" which is similar to the ground truth MCQ. However, none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose the most similar one, I would choose Question 1, but with a note that it's not a perfect match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

was the I Ching, an ancient Chinese divination text. Using just a handful of coins, the I Ching allows readers

were music, then where do we draw the line? But like a bold explorer, Cage didn't
want to be bound by restrictions, and he certainly didn't want
to follow old rules. He dedicated himself to shattering
our expectations, creating a series
of once in a lifetime experiences that continue encouraging 
musicians and audiences to embrace the unexpected.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1960, American composer John Cage 
went on national television to share his latest work. But rather than employing
traditional instruments, Cage appeared surrounded 
by household clutter, including a bathtub, ice cubes,
a toy fish, a pressure cooker, a rubber duck, and several radios. Armed with these tools and a stopwatch,
he performed “Water Walk,” setting off a series of sounds
with a serious expression and incredible precision. Some viewers found
the performance hysterical, while others thought it was
completely absurd. But most people watching likely shared 
the same question: is this even music? This question is harder to answer
than you might think. What we determine as music often
depends on our expectations. For example, imagine you’re 
in a jazz club listening to the rhythmic honking of horns. Most people would agree
that this is music. But if you were on the highway hearing
the same thing, many would call it noise. After all, car horns aren’t instruments and these drivers aren’t 
musicians... right? Expectations like these influence how
we categorize everything we hear. We typically think something sounds 
more musical if it uses a recognizable structure 
or popular sounds arranged in well-known patterns. And even within the realm of music, we expect certain genres to use specific
instruments and harmonies. These expectations are based 
on existing musical traditions, but those traditions aren't set in stone. They vary across different cultures
and time periods. And in the early 20th century, when many artists were pushing 
the boundaries of their fields, John Cage wanted to discover 
what new kinds of music might exist beyond those constraints. He began pioneering new instruments
that blurred the lines between art and everyday life, and used surprising objects to reinvent
existing instruments. He also explored new ways for music
to mingle with other art forms. He and his creative and romantic partner,
Merce Cunningham, held recitals where Cage’s music
and Cunningham’s choreography would be created independently
before being performed together. But whatever his approach, Cage gleefully dared listeners to question
the boundaries between music and noise, as well as sound and silence. Perhaps the best example is one of Cage’s
most famous compositions— a solo piano piece consisting of nothing
but musical rests for four minutes and 33 seconds. This wasn’t intended as a prank,
but rather, as a question. Could the opening and closing
of a piano lid be music? What about the click of a stopwatch? The rustling, and perhaps even the
complaining, of a crowd? Like the white canvases
of his painting peers, Cage asked the audience to question 
their expectations about what music was. And while the piece didn’t evoke the drama
of some traditional compositions, it certainly elicited a strong
emotional response. Cage’s work frequently prioritized
these spontaneous, ephemeral experiences over precise, predictable performances. He even developed processes that left some
compositional decisions up to chance. One of his favorite such systems
was the I Ching, an ancient Chinese divination text. Using just a handful of coins, the I Ching allows readers 
to produce a pattern of lines which can be interpreted
to answer questions and offer fortunes. But Cage adapted these patterns
into a series of tables that generated different musical 
durations, tempos, and dynamics. Eventually, he even used early computers
to help produce these random parameters. For some pieces, Cage went even further, offering musicians incomplete compositions
notated with broad instructions, allowing them to compose on the fly
with the help of his guidelines. Some composers rejected Cage's
seemingly careless approach. They believed it was the composer’s job 
to organize sound and time for a specific, intentional purpose. After all, if these strange compositions 
were music, then where do we draw the line? But like a bold explorer, Cage didn't
want to be bound by restrictions, and he certainly didn't want
to follow old rules. He dedicated himself to shattering
our expectations, creating a series
of once in a lifetime experiences that continue encouraging 
musicians and audiences to embrace the unexpected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was the title of Cage’s well-known “silent” piece?
Options: A. 4’33”, B. Water Walk, C. Living Room Music, D. 0’00”
Correct Option: A

A clearer definition of what constitutes "music" Correct Option: C

In 1960, American composer John Cage 
went on national television to share his latest work. But rather than employing
traditional instruments, Cage appeared surrounded 
by household clutter, including a bathtub, ice cubes,
a toy fish, a pressure cooker, a rubber duck, and several radios. Armed with these tools and a stopwatch,
he performed “Water Walk,” setting off a series of sounds
with a serious expression and incredible precision. Some viewers found
the performance hysterical, while others thought it was
completely absurd. But most people watching likely shared 
the same question: is this even music? This question is harder to answer
than you might think. What we determine as music often
depends on our expectations. For example, imagine you’re 
in a jazz club listening to the rhythmic honking of horns. Most people would agree
that this is music. But if you were on the highway hearing
the same thing, many would call it noise. After all, car horns aren’t instruments and these drivers aren’t 
musicians... right? Expectations like these influence how
we categorize everything we hear. We typically think something sounds 
more musical if it uses a recognizable structure 
or popular sounds arranged in well-known patterns. And even within the realm of music, we expect certain genres to use specific
instruments and harmonies. These expectations are based 
on existing musical traditions, but those traditions aren't set in stone. They vary across different cultures
and time periods. And in the early 20th century, when many artists were pushing

that blurred the lines between art and everyday life, and used surprising objects to reinvent

to mingle with other art forms. He and his creative and romantic partner,
Merce Cunningham, held recitals where Cage’s music
and Cunningham’s choreography would be created independently
before being performed together. But whatever his approach, Cage gleefully dared listeners to question
the boundaries between music and noise, as well as sound and silence. Perhaps the best example is one of Cage’s

musicians and audiences to embrace the unexpected.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
I'm McKenna Pope. I'm 14 years old. And when I was 13, I convinced one of the largest toy companies, toy makers in the world, Hasbro, to change the way that they marketed one of their best-selling products. So, allow me to tell you about it. So, I have a brother, Gavin. When this whole shebang happened, he was four. He loved to cook. He was always getting ingredients out of the fridge and mixing them into these, needless to say, uneatable concoctions or making invisible macaroni and cheese. He wanted to be a chef really badly. And, so what better gift for someone, for a kid who wanted to be a chef, than an Easy Bake Oven, right? I mean, we all had those when we were little. And he wanted one so badly. But then, he started to realize something. In the commercials and on the boxes for the Easy Bake Oven, Hasbro marketed them specifically to girls. And the way that they did this was they would only feature girls on the boxes or in the commercials, and there would be flowery prints all over the ovens, and it would be in bright pink and purple. Very gender-specific colors to females, right? So, it kind of was sending a message that only girls are supposed to cook. Boys aren't. And this discouraged my brother a lot. He thought that he wasn't supposed to want to be a chef. because that was something girls did. Girls cooked, boys didn't. Or so, the message that Hasbro was sending. And this got me thinking, "God, I wish there was a way I could change this, that I could have my voice heard by Hasbro, so I could ask them and tell them what they were doing wrong and ask them to change it." And that got me thinking about a website that I had learned about a few months prior called Change.org. Change.org is an online petition-sharing platform, where you can create a petition and share it across all these social media networks, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever you can think of. And so, I created a petition, along with a YouTube video that I added to the petition, basically asking Hasbro to change the way that they marketed it, in featuring boys in the commercials and on the boxes, and most of all creating them in less gender-specific colors. So, this petititon started to take off, like humongously fast, you have no idea. I was getting interviewed by all these national news outlets and press outlets, and it was amazing. In three weeks, maybe three and a half, I had 46,000 signatures on this petition. (Applause) Thank you. So, needless to say, it was crazy. Eventually, Hasbro themselves invited me to their headquarters so they could go and unveil their new Easy Bake Oven product to me, in black, silver and blue. It was literally one of the best moments of my life. It was like "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory." That thing was amazing. What I didn't realize at the time, however, was that I had become an activist. I could change something that, even as a kid, or maybe even especially as a kid, my voice mattered. And your voice matters, too! I want to let you know that it's not going to be easy, and it wasn't easy for me because I faced a lot of obstacles. People online, and sometimes even in real life, were disrespectful to me and my family and talked about how the whole thing was a waste of time, and it really discouraged me. And actually, I have some examples because what's better revenge than displaying their idiocy? So, let's see. From username Liquidsword29, interesting usernames we have here, "Disgusting liberal moms making their son's gay." Liquidsword29, really? Really? Okay, how about from Whiteboy77AGS, "People always need something to 'female dog' about." From Jeffrey Gutierrez, "OMG shut up! You just want money and attention." So, it was comments like these that really discouraged me from wanting to make change in the future because I thought, "People don't care. People think it's a waste of time. And people are going to be disrespectful to me and my family." It hurt me. And it made me think, "What's the point in making change in the future?" But then I started to realize something. Haters gonna hate. Come on, say it with me! One, two, three, Haters gonna hate! So let your haters hate, you know what! And make your change because I know you can. I look out into this crowd, and I see 400 people who came out because they wanted to know how they could make a change. And I know that you can, and all of you watching at home can, too, because you have so much that you can do and that you believe in. And you can trade it across all the social media, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever else you can think of. And you can make that change. You can take what you believe in and turn it into a cause and change it. And that spark that you've been hearing about all day today you can use that spark that you have within you and turn it into a fire. Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What percentage of chefs are male?
Options: A. 25%, B. 30%, C. 50%, D. 70%
Correct Option: D

That only adults can make a difference., C. That her voice mattered, and she could make a change, even as a kid., D. That social media is not an effective tool for creating change. Correct Option: C

Ignore the haters and focus on your goal., C. Let the haters motivate you to work harder and make a change., D. Wait until you're older and more experienced. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
I'm McKenna Pope. I'm 14 years old. And when I was 13, I convinced one of the largest toy companies, toy makers in the world, Hasbro, to change the way that they marketed one of their best-selling products. So, allow me to tell you about it. So, I have a brother, Gavin. When this whole shebang happened, he was four. He loved to cook. He was always getting ingredients out of the fridge and mixing them into these, needless to say, uneatable concoctions or making invisible macaroni and cheese. He wanted to be a chef really badly. And, so what better gift for someone, for a kid who wanted to be a chef, than an Easy Bake Oven, right? I mean, we all had those when we were little. And he wanted one so badly. But then, he started to realize something. In the commercials and on the boxes for the Easy Bake Oven, Hasbro marketed them specifically to girls. And the way that they did this was they would only feature girls on the boxes or in the commercials, and there would be flowery prints all over the ovens, and it would be in bright pink and purple. Very gender-specific colors to females, right? So, it kind of was sending a message that only girls are supposed to cook. Boys aren't. And this discouraged my brother a lot. He thought that he wasn't supposed to want to be a chef. because that was something girls did. Girls cooked, boys didn't. Or so, the message that Hasbro was sending. And this got me thinking, "God, I wish there was a way I could change this, that I could have my voice heard by Hasbro, so I could ask them and tell them what they were doing wrong and ask them to change it." And that got me thinking about a website that I had learned about a few months prior called Change.org. Change.org is an online petition-sharing platform, where you can create a petition and share it across all these social media networks, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever you can think of. And so, I created a petition, along with a YouTube video that I added to the petition, basically asking Hasbro to change the way that they marketed it, in featuring boys in the commercials and on the boxes, and most of all creating them in less gender-specific colors. So, this petititon started to take off, like humongously fast, you have no idea. I was getting interviewed by all these national news outlets and press outlets, and it was amazing. In three weeks, maybe three and a half, I had 46,000 signatures on this petition. (Applause) Thank you. So, needless to say, it was crazy. Eventually, Hasbro themselves invited me to their headquarters so they could go and unveil their new Easy Bake Oven product to me, in black, silver and blue. It was literally one of the best moments of my life. It was like "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory." That thing was amazing. What I didn't realize at the time, however, was that I had become an activist. I could change something that, even as a kid, or maybe even especially as a kid, my voice mattered. And your voice matters, too! I want to let you know that it's not going to be easy, and it wasn't easy for me because I faced a lot of obstacles. People online, and sometimes even in real life, were disrespectful to me and my family and talked about how the whole thing was a waste of time, and it really discouraged me. And actually, I have some examples because what's better revenge than displaying their idiocy? So, let's see. From username Liquidsword29, interesting usernames we have here, "Disgusting liberal moms making their son's gay." Liquidsword29, really? Really? Okay, how about from Whiteboy77AGS, "People always need something to 'female dog' about." From Jeffrey Gutierrez, "OMG shut up! You just want money and attention." So, it was comments like these that really discouraged me from wanting to make change in the future because I thought, "People don't care. People think it's a waste of time. And people are going to be disrespectful to me and my family." It hurt me. And it made me think, "What's the point in making change in the future?" But then I started to realize something. Haters gonna hate. Come on, say it with me! One, two, three, Haters gonna hate! So let your haters hate, you know what! And make your change because I know you can. I look out into this crowd, and I see 400 people who came out because they wanted to know how they could make a change. And I know that you can, and all of you watching at home can, too, because you have so much that you can do and that you believe in. And you can trade it across all the social media, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever else you can think of. And you can make that change. You can take what you believe in and turn it into a cause and change it. And that spark that you've been hearing about all day today you can use that spark that you have within you and turn it into a fire. Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: As of December 2012, what percentage of Easy Bake Oven commercials were targeted towards both genders:
Options: A. 0%, B. 25%, C. 50%, D. 70%
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main issue that McKenna Pope's brother, Gavin, faced when he wanted an Easy Bake Oven? Options: A. The oven was too expensive., B. The oven was not available in stores., C. The oven was marketed specifically to girls, discouraging him from wanting it., D. The oven was not suitable for children his age. Correct Option: C
Question 2: What platform did McKenna use to create a petition and share it with others? Options: A. Facebook, B. Change.org, C. Twitter, D. YouTube Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the outcome of McKenna's petition, and how did Hasbro respond? Options: A. The petition failed to gain traction, and Hasbro ignored it., B. The petition gained some attention, but Hasbro refused to make changes., C. The petition gained significant attention, and Hasbro invited McKenna to their headquarters to unveil a new, more inclusive Easy Bake Oven product., D. The petition was deleted, and Hasbro issued a statement criticizing McKenna's efforts. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What lesson did McKenna learn from her experience, despite facing obstacles and negative comments? Options: A. That she should give up on trying to make a change., B. That only adults can make a difference., C. That her voice mattered, and she could make a change, even as a kid., D. That social media is not an effective tool for creating change. Correct Option: C
Question 5: How did McKenna feel when she faced negative comments and disrespect from people online and in real life? Options: A. She felt motivated and encouraged to continue her efforts., B. She felt neutral and unaffected by the comments., C. She felt discouraged and hurt by the comments., D. She felt angry and defensive. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the significance of the new Easy Bake Oven product that Hasbro unveiled to McKenna? Options: A. It was a new color, but still marketed only to girls., B. It was a new design, but still had the same gender-specific features., C. It was a more inclusive product, featuring boys in the commercials and on the boxes, and available in less gender-specific colors., D. It was a more expensive version of the original product. Correct Option: C
Question 7: If you were in McKenna's shoes, how would you respond to negative comments and haters? Options: A. I would give up and abandon my efforts., B. I would ignore them and focus on my goal., C. I would engage with them and try to change their minds., D. I would let their hate motivate me to work harder and make a change. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the main message that McKenna conveyed to her audience? Options: A. That only certain people can make a change., B. That making a change is easy and requires no effort., C. That everyone has the power to make a change, and their voice matters., D. That social media is the only way to create change. Correct Option: C
Question 9: How did McKenna's experience with creating a petition and advocating for change affect her? Options: A. It made her realize that she was too young to make a difference., B. It made her feel powerless and ineffective., C. It made her realize that she had become an activist and that her voice mattered., D. It made her give up on trying to make a change. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What advice would McKenna give to someone who wants to make a change but is facing obstacles and negative comments? Options: A. Give up and abandon your efforts., B. Ignore the haters and focus on your goal., C. Let the haters motivate you to work harder and make a change., D. Wait until you're older and more experienced. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is:

**Question 6: What was the significance of the new Easy Bake Oven product that Hasbro unveiled to McKenna?**

Although this question does not directly ask about the percentage of Easy Bake Oven commercials targeted towards both genders, it does address the outcome of McKenna's petition and the changes made by Hasbro. The correct option (C) mentions that the new product was more inclusive, featuring boys in the commercials and on the boxes, and available in less gender-specific colors. This implies that the previous commercials were not targeted towards both genders, which aligns with the intent of the ground truth MCQ.

However, if I had to choose a question that more closely matches the ground truth MCQ, I would suggest creating a new question that directly addresses the percentage of Easy Bake Oven commercials targeted towards both genders. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 3

**Transcript**:
I'm McKenna Pope. I'm 14 years old. And when I was 13, I convinced one of the largest toy companies, toy makers in the world, Hasbro, to change the way that they marketed one of their best-selling products. So, allow me to tell you about it. So, I have a brother, Gavin. When this whole shebang happened, he was four. He loved to cook. He was always getting ingredients out of the fridge and mixing them into these, needless to say, uneatable concoctions or making invisible macaroni and cheese. He wanted to be a chef really badly. And, so what better gift for someone, for a kid who wanted to be a chef, than an Easy Bake Oven, right? I mean, we all had those when we were little. And he wanted one so badly. But then, he started to realize something. In the commercials and on the boxes for the Easy Bake Oven, Hasbro marketed them specifically to girls. And the way that they did this was they would only feature girls on the boxes or in the commercials, and there would be flowery prints all over the ovens, and it would be in bright pink and purple. Very gender-specific colors to females, right? So, it kind of was sending a message that only girls are supposed to cook. Boys aren't. And this discouraged my brother a lot. He thought that he wasn't supposed to want to be a chef. because that was something girls did. Girls cooked, boys didn't. Or so, the message that Hasbro was sending. And this got me thinking, "God, I wish there was a way I could change this, that I could have my voice heard by Hasbro, so I could ask them and tell them what they were doing wrong and ask them to change it." And that got me thinking about a website that I had learned about a few months prior called Change.org. Change.org is an online petition-sharing platform, where you can create a petition and share it across all these social media networks, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever you can think of. And so, I created a petition, along with a YouTube video that I added to the petition, basically asking Hasbro to change the way that they marketed it, in featuring boys in the commercials and on the boxes, and most of all creating them in less gender-specific colors. So, this petititon started to take off, like humongously fast, you have no idea. I was getting interviewed by all these national news outlets and press outlets, and it was amazing. In three weeks, maybe three and a half, I had 46,000 signatures on this petition. (Applause) Thank you. So, needless to say, it was crazy. Eventually, Hasbro themselves invited me to their headquarters so they could go and unveil their new Easy Bake Oven product to me, in black, silver and blue. It was literally one of the best moments of my life. It was like "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory." That thing was amazing. What I didn't realize at the time, however, was that I had become an activist. I could change something that, even as a kid, or maybe even especially as a kid, my voice mattered. And your voice matters, too! I want to let you know that it's not going to be easy, and it wasn't easy for me because I faced a lot of obstacles. People online, and sometimes even in real life, were disrespectful to me and my family and talked about how the whole thing was a waste of time, and it really discouraged me. And actually, I have some examples because what's better revenge than displaying their idiocy? So, let's see. From username Liquidsword29, interesting usernames we have here, "Disgusting liberal moms making their son's gay." Liquidsword29, really? Really? Okay, how about from Whiteboy77AGS, "People always need something to 'female dog' about." From Jeffrey Gutierrez, "OMG shut up! You just want money and attention." So, it was comments like these that really discouraged me from wanting to make change in the future because I thought, "People don't care. People think it's a waste of time. And people are going to be disrespectful to me and my family." It hurt me. And it made me think, "What's the point in making change in the future?" But then I started to realize something. Haters gonna hate. Come on, say it with me! One, two, three, Haters gonna hate! So let your haters hate, you know what! And make your change because I know you can. I look out into this crowd, and I see 400 people who came out because they wanted to know how they could make a change. And I know that you can, and all of you watching at home can, too, because you have so much that you can do and that you believe in. And you can trade it across all the social media, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever else you can think of. And you can make that change. You can take what you believe in and turn it into a cause and change it. And that spark that you've been hearing about all day today you can use that spark that you have within you and turn it into a fire. Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many social networking sites are available to try and start change in America?
Options: A. 2, B. 6, C. 8+
Correct Option: C
