and history is trapped in them.” Baldwin’s role in the Civil Rights 
movement went beyond observing and reporting. He also traveled through the 
American South attending rallies giving lectures 
of his own. He debated both white politicians 
and black activists, including Malcolm X, and served as a liaison between black 
activists and intellectuals and white establishment leaders 
like Robert Kennedy. Because of Baldwin’s unique ability to articulate the causes 
of social turbulence in a way that white audiences 
were willing to hear, Kennedy and others tended to see 
him as an ambassador for black Americans — a label Baldwin rejected. And at the same time, his faculty with words led the 
FBI to view him as a threat. Even within the Civil Rights movement, Baldwin could sometimes feel 
like an outsider for his choice to live abroad,
as well as his sexuality, which he explored openly 
in his writing at a time when homophobia ran rampant. Throughout his life, Baldwin considered it his role
to bear witness. Unlike many of his peers, he lived to see some of the
victories of the Civil Rights movement, but the continuing racial inequalities in 
the United States weighed heavily on him. Though he may have felt trapped 
in his moment in history, his words have made generations 
of people feel known, while guiding them toward a more 
nuanced understanding of society’s most complex issues.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Over the course of the 1960s, the FBI amassed almost 
two thousand documents in an investigation into one 
of America’s most celebrated minds. The subject of this inquiry 
was a writer named James Baldwin. At the time, the FBI investigated many 
artists and thinkers, but most of their files were a 
fraction the size of Baldwin’s. During the years when the FBI hounded him, he became one of the best-selling
black authors in the world. So what made James Baldwin loom 
so large in the imaginations of both the public and the authorities? Born in Harlem in 1924, he was the oldest of nine children. At age fourteen,
he began to work as a preacher. By delivering sermons,
he developed his voice as a writer, but also grew conflicted about the Church’s stance on racial inequality and homosexuality. After high school, he began writing novels and essays
while taking a series of odd jobs. But the issues that had driven him 
away from the Church were still inescapable in his daily life. Constantly confronted with racism 
and homophobia, he was angry and disillusioned, 
and yearned for a less restricted life. So in 1948, 
at the age of 24, he moved to Paris on a writing fellowship. From France, he published his first novel, "Go Tell it on the Mountain," in 1953. Set in Harlem, the book explores the Church 
as a source of both repression and hope. It was popular with both black 
and white readers. As he earned acclaim for his fiction, Baldwin gathered his thoughts on race, 
class, culture and exile in his 1955 extended essay, 
"Notes of a Native Son." Meanwhile, the Civil Rights movement 
was gaining momentum in America. Black Americans were making incremental 
gains at registering to vote and voting, but were still denied basic dignities in 
schools, on buses, in the work force, and in the armed services. Though he lived primarily in France 
for the rest of his life, Baldwin was deeply invested in 
the movement, and keenly aware of his 
country’s unfulfilled promise. He had seen family, friends, 
and neighbors spiral into addiction, incarceration
and suicide. He believed their fates originated 
from the constraints of a segregated society. In 1963, he published "The Fire Next Time," an arresting portrait of racial strife in which he held white America 
accountable, but he also went further, arguing that racism hurt white people too. In his view, everyone was inextricably enmeshed 
in the same social fabric. He had long believed that: “People are trapped in history 
and history is trapped in them.” Baldwin’s role in the Civil Rights 
movement went beyond observing and reporting. He also traveled through the 
American South attending rallies giving lectures 
of his own. He debated both white politicians 
and black activists, including Malcolm X, and served as a liaison between black 
activists and intellectuals and white establishment leaders 
like Robert Kennedy. Because of Baldwin’s unique ability to articulate the causes 
of social turbulence in a way that white audiences 
were willing to hear, Kennedy and others tended to see 
him as an ambassador for black Americans — a label Baldwin rejected. And at the same time, his faculty with words led the 
FBI to view him as a threat. Even within the Civil Rights movement, Baldwin could sometimes feel 
like an outsider for his choice to live abroad,
as well as his sexuality, which he explored openly 
in his writing at a time when homophobia ran rampant. Throughout his life, Baldwin considered it his role
to bear witness. Unlike many of his peers, he lived to see some of the
victories of the Civil Rights movement, but the continuing racial inequalities in 
the United States weighed heavily on him. Though he may have felt trapped 
in his moment in history, his words have made generations 
of people feel known, while guiding them toward a more 
nuanced understanding of society’s most complex issues.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Baldwin was involved in the Civil Rights Movement and one of the famous activists he debated was:
Options: A. Bayard Rustin, B. Rosa Parks, C. Medgar Evers, D. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr, E. Malcolm X
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was James Baldwin born in 1924? Options: A. Paris, France, B. Harlem, New York, C. Los Angeles, California, D. Chicago, Illinois Correct Option: B
Question 2: At what age did James Baldwin begin working as a preacher, developing his voice as a writer? Options: A. 18 years old, B. 21 years old, C. 14 years old, D. 25 years old Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the title of James Baldwin's first novel, published in 1953, which explores the Church as a source of both repression and hope? Options: A. "Notes of a Native Son", B. "The Fire Next Time", C. "Go Tell it on the Mountain", D. "Giovanni's Room" Correct Option: C
Question 4: What was the primary reason the FBI viewed James Baldwin as a threat? Options: A. His involvement in the Civil Rights movement, B. His faculty with words and ability to articulate the causes of social turbulence, C. His decision to live abroad, D. His exploration of homophobia in his writing Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to James Baldwin, what was the impact of racism on American society? Options: A. It only hurt black people, B. It only hurt white people, C. It hurt both black and white people, as everyone is inextricably enmeshed in the same social fabric, D. It had no significant impact on American society Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was James Baldwin's role in the Civil Rights movement beyond observing and reporting? Options: A. He only attended rallies and gave lectures, B. He only debated white politicians and black activists, C. He served as a liaison between black activists and intellectuals and white establishment leaders, and also attended rallies, gave lectures, and debated politicians and activists, D. He had no role beyond observing and reporting Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why did James Baldwin reject the label of being an "ambassador for black Americans"? Options: A. He did not want to be associated with the Civil Rights movement, B. He felt that the label oversimplified his complex role as a writer and activist, C. He did not want to be seen as a representative of all black Americans, D. The transcript does not specify why Baldwin rejected the label Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the significance of James Baldwin's decision to live abroad, particularly in Paris? Options: A. It allowed him to escape the racism and homophobia he faced in America, B. It gave him a unique perspective on American society and the Civil Rights movement, C. It made him an outsider within the Civil Rights movement, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: How did James Baldwin's writing style and ability to articulate complex social issues contribute to his impact on American society? Options: A. His writing style was confrontational and alienated white audiences, B. His writing style was too simplistic and failed to capture the complexity of social issues, C. His writing style was nuanced and articulate, making him a key voice in the Civil Rights movement, D. His writing style had no significant impact on American society Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was James Baldwin's ultimate goal as a writer and activist, according to the transcript? Options: A. To become a best-selling author, B. To be seen as an ambassador for black Americans, C. To bear witness to the complexities of American society and guide people toward a more nuanced understanding of social issues, D. To escape the racism and homophobia he faced in America Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 6: What was James Baldwin's role in the Civil Rights movement beyond observing and reporting?**

However, this question does not specifically ask about the famous activist James Baldwin debated. A more relevant question would be needed to perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. 

Since there isn't a perfect match, I will choose the question that is most relevant to the Civil Rights Movement.

But a closer match can be found in the options of **Question 6**. It mentions that James Baldwin "debated both white politicians and black activists, including" but does not specifically ask about it.

If I really have to choose, I will select **Question 6** as the closest match, but keep in mind that it is not a perfect match.

Index: **6**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Love is often described as heartwarming,
heart-wrenching and even heartbreaking. So, what does the brain have
to do with it? Everything! The journey from first spark to last tear
is guided by a symphony of neurochemicals and brain systems. As you begin to fall for someone, you may find yourself excessively
daydreaming about them and wanting to spend more and more
time together. This first stage of love is what
psychologists call infatuation, or passionate love. Your new relationship
can feel almost intoxicating, and when it comes to the brain,
that’s not far from the truth. Infatuated individuals show increased
activation in the ventral tegmental area. The VTA is the reward-processing 
and motivation hub of the brain, firing when you do things like 
eat a sweet treat, quench your thirst, or in more extreme cases,
take drugs of abuse. Activation releases the “feel good”
neurotransmitter dopamine, teaching your brain to repeat behaviors 
in anticipation of receiving the same initial reward. This increased VTA activity is the
reason love's not only euphoric, but also draws you towards
your new partner. At this first stage, it may be hard to see
any faults in your new perfect partner. This haze is thanks
to love’s influence on higher cortical brain regions. Some newly infatuated individuals
show decreased activity in the brain’s cognitive center, 
the prefrontal cortex. As activation of this region allows us 
to engage in critical thought and pass judgment, it’s not surprising we tend to see 
new relationships through rose-colored glasses. While this first stage of love can be an intense rollercoaster of emotions
and brain activity, it typically only lasts a few months, making way for the more long-lasting
stage of love, known as attachment,
or compassionate love. As your relationship develops, you may feel more relaxed 
and committed to your partner thanks in large part to two hormones:
oxytocin and vasopressin. Known as pair-bonding hormones, they signal trust, 
feelings of social support and attachment. In this way, romantic love 
is not unlike other forms of love, as these hormones also help bond
families and friendships. Further, oxytocin can inhibit 
the release of stress hormones, which is why spending time 
with a loved one can feel so relaxing. As early love's suspension
of judgment fades, it can be replaced by a more honest
understanding and deeper connection. Alternatively, as your rose-colored
glasses begin to lose their tint, problems in your relationship
may become more evident. No matter the reason 
a relationship ends, we can blame the pain that accompanies
heartbreak on the brain. The distress of a breakup activates
the insular cortex, a region that processes pain— both physical, 
like spraining your ankle, as well as social, 
like the feelings of rejection. As days pass, you may find yourself
once again daydreaming about or craving contact with your lost partner. The drive to reach out may
feel overwhelming, like an extreme hunger or thirst. When looking at photos
of a former partner, heartbroken individuals again show
increased activity in the VTA, the motivation and reward center 
that drove feelings of longing during the initial stages 
of the relationship. This emotional whirlwind also likely
activates your body’s alarm system, the stress axis, leaving you feeling 
shaken and restless. As time goes on, higher cortical regions which oversee 
reasoning and impulse control, can pump the brakes on this distress
and craving signaling. Given that these regions
are still maturing and making connections
through adolescence, it's no wonder that first heartbreak
can feel particularly agonizing. Activities like exercise, 
spending time with friends, or even listening to your favorite song can tame this heartbreak stress response, while also triggering the release 
of feel good neurotransmitter dopamine. And given time and the support, most can heal and learn from even
the most devastating heartbreak.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the first stage of love, according to scientists?
Options: A. Obsession, B. Pining, C. Infatuation , D. Hallucination
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the term used by psychologists to describe the first stage of love, characterized by excessive daydreaming and a desire to spend more time with the person? Options: A. Infatuation, B. Attachment, C. Compassionate love, D. Passionate hate Correct Option: A
Question 2: Which brain region is responsible for the release of the "feel good" neurotransmitter dopamine during the infatuation stage of love? Options: A. Prefrontal cortex, B. Ventral tegmental area (VTA), C. Insular cortex, D. Cerebellum Correct Option: B
Question 3: Imagine you have a friend who recently went through a breakup and is struggling with feelings of heartbreak. Based on the information provided, what activity would you recommend to help them cope with their emotions? Options: A. Watching romantic movies, B. Spending time with friends, C. Listening to sad music, D. Avoiding social interactions Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary function of the hormones oxytocin and vasopressin in the context of romantic love? Options: A. To stimulate the release of dopamine, B. To signal trust, feelings of social support, and attachment, C. To increase activity in the prefrontal cortex, D. To decrease activity in the VTA Correct Option: B
Question 5: Analyze the relationship between the brain's reward-processing system and the experience of love. How do the activation of the VTA and the release of dopamine contribute to the feelings of euphoria and attachment? Options: A. The VTA and dopamine release are only involved in the attachment stage of love., B. The VTA and dopamine release are only involved in the infatuation stage of love., C. The VTA and dopamine release contribute to the feelings of euphoria and attachment by associating the loved one with pleasure and reward., D. The VTA and dopamine release have no role in the experience of love. Correct Option: C
Question 6: Evaluate the statement: "Love is a purely emotional experience and has no basis in brain activity." Do you agree or disagree, and why? Options: A. Agree, love is only an emotional experience., B. Disagree, love is influenced by a complex interplay of brain systems and neurochemicals., C. Partially agree, love is primarily emotional but has some basis in brain activity., D. Partially disagree, love is primarily based on brain activity but has some emotional components. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where people tend to see their new partner as perfect and flawless during the infatuation stage of love? Options: A. Rose-colored glasses, B. Love blindness, C. Infatuation haze, D. Attachment bias Correct Option: A
Question 8: Synthesize the information provided about the different stages of love. How do the infatuation and attachment stages differ in terms of brain activity and hormone release? Options: A. The infatuation stage is characterized by increased VTA activity and dopamine release, while the attachment stage is characterized by increased oxytocin and vasopressin release., B. The infatuation stage is characterized by increased oxytocin and vasopressin release, while the attachment stage is characterized by increased VTA activity and dopamine release., C. The infatuation stage is characterized by decreased VTA activity and dopamine release, while the attachment stage is characterized by increased oxytocin and vasopressin release., D. The infatuation stage is characterized by increased VTA activity and dopamine release, while the attachment stage is characterized by decreased oxytocin and vasopressin release. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the role of the insular cortex in the experience of heartbreak? Options: A. It processes physical pain only., B. It processes social pain only., C. It processes both physical and social pain., D. It has no role in the experience of heartbreak. Correct Option: C
Question 10: Compare and contrast the effects of love on the brain's cognitive center, the prefrontal cortex, during the infatuation and attachment stages. How do these effects influence our perception of our partner? Options: A. During infatuation, the prefrontal cortex shows increased activity, leading to a more critical evaluation of our partner. During attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows decreased activity, leading to a more idealized view of our partner., B. During infatuation, the prefrontal cortex shows decreased activity, leading to a more idealized view of our partner. During attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows increased activity, leading to a more critical evaluation of our partner., C. During both infatuation and attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows increased activity, leading to a more critical evaluation of our partner., D. During both infatuation and attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows decreased activity, leading to a more idealized view of our partner. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the first stage of love, and both have "infatuation" as the correct answer. The options in Question 1 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with "infatuation" being the correct answer and the other options being plausible but incorrect.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

**Transcript**:
Love is often described as heartwarming,
heart-wrenching and even heartbreaking. So, what does the brain have
to do with it? Everything! The journey from first spark to last tear
is guided by a symphony of neurochemicals and brain systems. As you begin to fall for someone, you may find yourself excessively

time together. This first stage of love is what
psychologists call infatuation, or passionate love. Your new relationship
can feel almost intoxicating, and when it comes to the brain,
that’s not far from the truth. Infatuated individuals show increased

to love’s influence on higher cortical brain regions. Some newly infatuated individuals

the prefrontal cortex. As activation of this region allows us 
to engage in critical thought and pass judgment, it’s not surprising we tend to see

and brain activity, it typically only lasts a few months, making way for the more long-lasting
stage of love, known as attachment,
or compassionate love. As your relationship develops, you may feel more relaxed 
and committed to your partner thanks in large part to two hormones:

reasoning and impulse control, can pump the brakes on this distress
and craving signaling. Given that these regions
are still maturing and making connections
through adolescence, it's no wonder that first heartbreak

of feel good neurotransmitter dopamine. And given time and the support, most can heal and learn from even
the most devastating heartbreak.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:

heart-wrenching and even heartbreaking. So, what does the brain have
to do with it? Everything! The journey from first spark to last tear
is guided by a symphony of neurochemicals and brain systems. As you begin to fall for someone, you may find yourself excessively

and committed to your partner thanks in large part to two hormones:

shaken and restless. As time goes on, higher cortical regions which oversee

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the infatuation stage of love, scientists have observed a _________ in activity the prefrontal cortex (the brain’s cognitive center)
Options: A. Increase , B. Decrease
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the term used by psychologists to describe the first stage of love, characterized by excessive daydreaming and a desire to spend more time with the person? Options: A. Infatuation, B. Attachment, C. Compassionate love, D. Passionate hate Correct Option: A

Question 4: What is the primary function of the hormones oxytocin and vasopressin in the context of romantic love? Options: A. To stimulate the release of dopamine, B. To signal trust, feelings of social support, and attachment, C. To increase activity in the prefrontal cortex, D. To decrease activity in the VTA Correct Option: B
Question 5: Analyze the relationship between the brain's reward-processing system and the experience of love. How do the activation of the VTA and the release of dopamine contribute to the feelings of euphoria and attachment? Options: A. The VTA and dopamine release are only involved in the attachment stage of love., B. The VTA and dopamine release are only involved in the infatuation stage of love., C. The VTA and dopamine release contribute to the feelings of euphoria and attachment by associating the loved one with pleasure and reward., D. The VTA and dopamine release have no role in the experience of love. Correct Option: C
Question 6: Evaluate the statement: "Love is a purely emotional experience and has no basis in brain activity." Do you agree or disagree, and why? Options: A. Agree, love is only an emotional experience., B. Disagree, love is influenced by a complex interplay of brain systems and neurochemicals., C. Partially agree, love is primarily emotional but has some basis in brain activity., D. Partially disagree, love is primarily based on brain activity but has some emotional components. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where people tend to see their new partner as perfect and flawless during the infatuation stage of love? Options: A. Rose-colored glasses, B. Love blindness, C. Infatuation haze, D. Attachment bias Correct Option: A
Question 8: Synthesize the information provided about the different stages of love. How do the infatuation and attachment stages differ in terms of brain activity and hormone release? Options: A. The infatuation stage is characterized by increased VTA activity and dopamine release, while the attachment stage is characterized by increased oxytocin and vasopressin release., B. The infatuation stage is characterized by increased oxytocin and vasopressin release, while the attachment stage is characterized by increased VTA activity and dopamine release., C. The infatuation stage is characterized by decreased VTA activity and dopamine release, while the attachment stage is characterized by increased oxytocin and vasopressin release., D. The infatuation stage is characterized by increased VTA activity and dopamine release, while the attachment stage is characterized by decreased oxytocin and vasopressin release. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the role of the insular cortex in the experience of heartbreak? Options: A. It processes physical pain only., B. It processes social pain only., C. It processes both physical and social pain., D. It has no role in the experience of heartbreak. Correct Option: C
Question 10: Compare and contrast the effects of love on the brain's cognitive center, the prefrontal cortex, during the infatuation and attachment stages. How do these effects influence our perception of our partner? Options: A. During infatuation, the prefrontal cortex shows increased activity, leading to a more critical evaluation of our partner. During attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows decreased activity, leading to a more idealized view of our partner., B. During infatuation, the prefrontal cortex shows decreased activity, leading to a more idealized view of our partner. During attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows increased activity, leading to a more critical evaluation of our partner., C. During both infatuation and attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows increased activity, leading to a more critical evaluation of our partner., D. During both infatuation and attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows decreased activity, leading to a more idealized view of our partner. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10. 

This question is about the effect of love on the brain's cognitive center, the prefrontal cortex, during the infatuation and attachment stages, and how these effects influence our perception of our partner. The correct option, B, states that during infatuation, the prefrontal cortex shows decreased activity, leading to a more idealized view of our partner. This matches the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the change in activity in the prefrontal cortex during the infatuation stage of love and has the correct option as "Decrease". 

Although Question 10 is not an exact match to the ground truth MCQ, it is the most similar in terms of question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Love is often described as heartwarming,
heart-wrenching and even heartbreaking. So, what does the brain have
to do with it? Everything! The journey from first spark to last tear
is guided by a symphony of neurochemicals and brain systems. As you begin to fall for someone, you may find yourself excessively
daydreaming about them and wanting to spend more and more
time together. This first stage of love is what
psychologists call infatuation, or passionate love. Your new relationship
can feel almost intoxicating, and when it comes to the brain,
that’s not far from the truth. Infatuated individuals show increased
activation in the ventral tegmental area. The VTA is the reward-processing 
and motivation hub of the brain, firing when you do things like 
eat a sweet treat, quench your thirst, or in more extreme cases,
take drugs of abuse. Activation releases the “feel good”
neurotransmitter dopamine, teaching your brain to repeat behaviors 
in anticipation of receiving the same initial reward. This increased VTA activity is the
reason love's not only euphoric, but also draws you towards
your new partner. At this first stage, it may be hard to see
any faults in your new perfect partner. This haze is thanks
to love’s influence on higher cortical brain regions. Some newly infatuated individuals
show decreased activity in the brain’s cognitive center, 
the prefrontal cortex. As activation of this region allows us 
to engage in critical thought and pass judgment, it’s not surprising we tend to see 
new relationships through rose-colored glasses. While this first stage of love can be an intense rollercoaster of emotions
and brain activity, it typically only lasts a few months, making way for the more long-lasting
stage of love, known as attachment,
or compassionate love. As your relationship develops, you may feel more relaxed 
and committed to your partner thanks in large part to two hormones:
oxytocin and vasopressin. Known as pair-bonding hormones, they signal trust, 
feelings of social support and attachment. In this way, romantic love 
is not unlike other forms of love, as these hormones also help bond
families and friendships. Further, oxytocin can inhibit 
the release of stress hormones, which is why spending time 
with a loved one can feel so relaxing. As early love's suspension
of judgment fades, it can be replaced by a more honest
understanding and deeper connection. Alternatively, as your rose-colored
glasses begin to lose their tint, problems in your relationship
may become more evident. No matter the reason 
a relationship ends, we can blame the pain that accompanies
heartbreak on the brain. The distress of a breakup activates
the insular cortex, a region that processes pain— both physical, 
like spraining your ankle, as well as social, 
like the feelings of rejection. As days pass, you may find yourself
once again daydreaming about or craving contact with your lost partner. The drive to reach out may
feel overwhelming, like an extreme hunger or thirst. When looking at photos
of a former partner, heartbroken individuals again show
increased activity in the VTA, the motivation and reward center 
that drove feelings of longing during the initial stages 
of the relationship. This emotional whirlwind also likely
activates your body’s alarm system, the stress axis, leaving you feeling 
shaken and restless. As time goes on, higher cortical regions which oversee 
reasoning and impulse control, can pump the brakes on this distress
and craving signaling. Given that these regions
are still maturing and making connections
through adolescence, it's no wonder that first heartbreak
can feel particularly agonizing. Activities like exercise, 
spending time with friends, or even listening to your favorite song can tame this heartbreak stress response, while also triggering the release 
of feel good neurotransmitter dopamine. And given time and the support, most can heal and learn from even
the most devastating heartbreak.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to scientists, what is the second stage of love?
Options: A. Companionship, B. Long-Term Commitment , C. Stage of Certainty, D. Attachment
Correct Option: D

Question 2: Which brain region is responsible for the release of the "feel good" neurotransmitter dopamine during the infatuation stage of love? Options: A. Prefrontal cortex, B. Ventral tegmental area (VTA), C. Insular cortex, D. Cerebellum Correct Option: B

Partially agree, love is primarily emotional but has some basis in brain activity., D. Partially disagree, love is primarily based on brain activity but has some emotional components. During attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows decreased activity, leading to a more idealized view of our partner., B. During infatuation, the prefrontal cortex shows decreased activity, leading to a more idealized view of our partner. During attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows increased activity, leading to a more critical evaluation of our partner., C. During both infatuation and attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows increased activity, leading to a more critical evaluation of our partner., D. During both infatuation and attachment, the prefrontal cortex shows decreased activity, leading to a more idealized view of our partner. Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
Love is often described as heartwarming,
heart-wrenching and even heartbreaking. So, what does the brain have
to do with it? Everything! The journey from first spark to last tear
is guided by a symphony of neurochemicals and brain systems. As you begin to fall for someone, you may find yourself excessively
daydreaming about them and wanting to spend more and more
time together. This first stage of love is what
psychologists call infatuation, or passionate love. Your new relationship
can feel almost intoxicating, and when it comes to the brain,
that’s not far from the truth. Infatuated individuals show increased
activation in the ventral tegmental area. The VTA is the reward-processing 
and motivation hub of the brain, firing when you do things like 
eat a sweet treat, quench your thirst, or in more extreme cases,
take drugs of abuse. Activation releases the “feel good”
neurotransmitter dopamine, teaching your brain to repeat behaviors 
in anticipation of receiving the same initial reward. This increased VTA activity is the
reason love's not only euphoric, but also draws you towards
your new partner. At this first stage, it may be hard to see
any faults in your new perfect partner. This haze is thanks
to love’s influence on higher cortical brain regions. Some newly infatuated individuals
show decreased activity in the brain’s cognitive center, 
the prefrontal cortex. As activation of this region allows us 
to engage in critical thought and pass judgment, it’s not surprising we tend to see 
new relationships through rose-colored glasses. While this first stage of love can be an intense rollercoaster of emotions
and brain activity, it typically only lasts a few months, making way for the more long-lasting
stage of love, known as attachment,
or compassionate love. As your relationship develops, you may feel more relaxed 
and committed to your partner thanks in large part to two hormones:
oxytocin and vasopressin. Known as pair-bonding hormones, they signal trust, 
feelings of social support and attachment. In this way, romantic love 
is not unlike other forms of love, as these hormones also help bond
families and friendships. Further, oxytocin can inhibit 
the release of stress hormones, which is why spending time 
with a loved one can feel so relaxing. As early love's suspension
of judgment fades, it can be replaced by a more honest
understanding and deeper connection. Alternatively, as your rose-colored
glasses begin to lose their tint, problems in your relationship
may become more evident. No matter the reason 
a relationship ends, we can blame the pain that accompanies
heartbreak on the brain. The distress of a breakup activates
the insular cortex, a region that processes pain— both physical, 
like spraining your ankle, as well as social, 
like the feelings of rejection. As days pass, you may find yourself
once again daydreaming about or craving contact with your lost partner. The drive to reach out may
feel overwhelming, like an extreme hunger or thirst. When looking at photos
of a former partner, heartbroken individuals again show

that drove feelings of longing during the initial stages 
of the relationship. This emotional whirlwind also likely

shaken and restless. As time goes on, higher cortical regions which oversee

and craving signaling. Given that these regions
are still maturing and making connections
through adolescence, it's no wonder that first heartbreak
can feel particularly agonizing. Activities like exercise, 
spending time with friends, or even listening to your favorite song can tame this heartbreak stress response, while also triggering the release 
of feel good neurotransmitter dopamine. And given time and the support, most can heal and learn from even
the most devastating heartbreak.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Following a devastating nuclear war, Lilith Iyapo awakens
after 250 years of stasis to find herself surrounded by a group 
of aliens called the Oankali. These highly evolved beings
want to trade DNA by breeding with humans so that each species’ genes 
can diversify and fortify the other. The only alternative they offer is 
sterilization of the entire human race. Should humanity take the leap into 
the biological unknown, or hold on to its identity and perish? Questions like this haunt 
Octavia Butler’s "Dawn," the first in her trilogy "Lilith’s Brood." A visionary storyteller who 
upended science fiction, Butler built stunning worlds 
throughout her work– and explored dilemmas that keep 
us awake at night. Born in 1947, Butler grew up shy and introverted in 
Pasadena, California. She dreamt up stories from an early age, and was soon scribbling these 
scenarios on paper. At twelve, she begged her mother 
for a typewriter after enduring a campy science fiction
film called "Devil Girl From Mars." Unimpressed with what she saw, Butler knew she could tell a better story. Much science fiction features 
white male heroes who blast aliens or become 
saviors of brown people. Butler wanted to write diverse characters
for diverse audiences. She brought nuance and depth to the 
representation of their experiences. For Butler, imagination was not only for planting 
the seeds of science fiction– but also a strategy for surviving an 
unjust world on one’s own terms. Her work often takes troubling 
features of the world such as discrimination on the basis of 
race, gender, class, or ability, and invites the reader to contemplate 
them in new contexts. One of her most beloved novels, the "Parable of the Sower," follows this pattern. It tells the story of Lauren Oya Olamina as she makes her way through a near-future
California, ruined by corporate greed, inequality, and environmental destruction. As she struggles with hyperempathy, or a condition in the novel that 
causes her to feel others’ pain, and less often, their pleasure. Lauren embarks on a quest with a group 
of refugees to find a place to thrive. There, they seek to live in accordance 
with Lauren’s found religion, Earthseed, which is based on the principle that humans must adapt to an 
ever-changing world. Lauren’s quest had roots 
in a real life event– California Prop 187, which attempted to deny undocumented
immigrants fundamental human rights, before it was deemed unconstitutional. Butler frequently incorporated 
contemporary news into her writing. In her 1998 sequel to "The Parable of the 
Sower," "Parable of the Talents," she wrote of a presidential candidate who controls Americans with virtual 
reality and “shock collars.” His slogan? “Make America great again.” While people have noted her prescience, Butler was also interested in 
re-examining history. For instance,
"Kindred" tells the story of a woman who is repeatedly
pulled back in time to the Maryland plantation 
of her ancestors. Early on, she learns that her mission 
is to save the life of the white man who will rape her great grandmother. If she doesn’t save him, 
she herself will cease to exist. This grim dilemma forces Dana to 
confront the ongoing trauma of slavery and sexual violence 
against Black women. With her stories of women 
founding new societies, time travelers overcoming 
historical strife, and interspecies bonding, Butler had a profound influence on 
the growing popularity of Afrofuturism. That’s a cultural movement where Black writers and artists who are 
inspired by the past, present and future, produce works that incorporate magic, 
history, technology and much more. As Lauren comes to learn in 
"Parable of the Sower," "All that you touch you Change. All that you Change Changes you. The only lasting truth is Change.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the name of the nationally recognized prize Butler was awarded for her fiction and nonfiction writing?
Options: A. Tony Award, B. Academy Award, C. Pulitzer Prize, D. MacArthur “Genius” Grant
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the novel by Octavia Butler that tells the story of Lilith Iyapo and her encounter with the Oankali aliens? Options: A. "Parable of the Sower", B. "Dawn", C. "Kindred", D. "Parable of the Talents" Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the main reason why the Oankali aliens want to breed with humans in the novel "Dawn"? Options: A. To create a new species of superhumans, B. To trade DNA and diversify each species' genes, C. To use humans as a food source, D. To study human behavior Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did Octavia Butler's personal experience with a science fiction film influence her writing career? Options: A. It inspired her to write more science fiction stories, B. It discouraged her from pursuing a writing career, C. It motivated her to write better science fiction stories than what she saw in the film, D. It had no impact on her writing career Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the name of the condition that the protagonist Lauren Oya Olamina suffers from in the novel "Parable of the Sower"? Options: A. Hyperempathy, B. Hypersensitivity, C. Empathy disorder, D. Emotional instability Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the main theme of Octavia Butler's novel "Kindred"? Options: A. The struggle for civil rights in the 1960s, B. The trauma of slavery and sexual violence against Black women, C. The power of love and relationships, D. The impact of technology on society Correct Option: B
Question 6: How does Octavia Butler's work relate to the cultural movement of Afrofuturism? Options: A. Her work is a critique of Afrofuturism, B. Her work is an example of Afrofuturism, C. Her work is unrelated to Afrofuturism, D. Her work is a precursor to Afrofuturism Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the name of the presidential candidate in Octavia Butler's novel "Parable of the Talents" who controls Americans with virtual reality and "shock collars"? Options: A. Not specified in the transcript, B. Donald Trump, C. Ronald Reagan, D. George W. Bush Correct Option: A
Question 8: How does Octavia Butler's work often incorporate contemporary news and events? Options: A. She includes news headlines as chapter titles, B. She uses real-life events as inspiration for her stories, C. She includes cameos of real-life figures in her stories, D. She uses news articles as dialogue in her stories Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the central dilemma faced by the protagonist Dana in the novel "Kindred"? Options: A. Whether to save the life of her great-grandmother or not, B. Whether to save the life of the white man who will rape her great-grandmother or not, C. Whether to stay in the present or travel back in time, D. Whether to confront her ancestors or not Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of the phrase "All that you touch you Change. All that you Change Changes you. The only lasting truth is Change" in the context of Octavia Butler's work? Options: A. It highlights the importance of tradition and stability, B. It emphasizes the power of individual agency and control, C. It underscores the idea that change is the only constant in life, D. It suggests that humans are powerless against the forces of change Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. The ground truth MCQ asks about a specific award won by Octavia Butler, while the generated MCQs cover various aspects of her life, work, and writing themes.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the broader context of Octavia Butler's life and achievements, I would select:

**None of the generated MCQs**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 2

To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Following a devastating nuclear war, Lilith Iyapo awakens
after 250 years of stasis to find herself surrounded by a group 
of aliens called the Oankali. These highly evolved beings
want to trade DNA by breeding with humans so that each species’ genes 
can diversify and fortify the other. The only alternative they offer is 
sterilization of the entire human race. Should humanity take the leap into 
the biological unknown, or hold on to its identity and perish? Questions like this haunt 
Octavia Butler’s "Dawn," the first in her trilogy "Lilith’s Brood." A visionary storyteller who 
upended science fiction, Butler built stunning worlds 
throughout her work– and explored dilemmas that keep 
us awake at night. Born in 1947, Butler grew up shy and introverted in 
Pasadena, California. She dreamt up stories from an early age, and was soon scribbling these 
scenarios on paper. At twelve, she begged her mother 
for a typewriter after enduring a campy science fiction
film called "Devil Girl From Mars." Unimpressed with what she saw, Butler knew she could tell a better story. Much science fiction features 
white male heroes who blast aliens or become 
saviors of brown people. Butler wanted to write diverse characters
for diverse audiences. She brought nuance and depth to the 
representation of their experiences. For Butler, imagination was not only for planting 
the seeds of science fiction– but also a strategy for surviving an 
unjust world on one’s own terms. Her work often takes troubling 
features of the world such as discrimination on the basis of 
race, gender, class, or ability, and invites the reader to contemplate 
them in new contexts. One of her most beloved novels, the "Parable of the Sower," follows this pattern. It tells the story of Lauren Oya Olamina as she makes her way through a near-future
California, ruined by corporate greed, inequality, and environmental destruction. As she struggles with hyperempathy, or a condition in the novel that 
causes her to feel others’ pain, and less often, their pleasure. Lauren embarks on a quest with a group 
of refugees to find a place to thrive. There, they seek to live in accordance 
with Lauren’s found religion, Earthseed, which is based on the principle that humans must adapt to an 
ever-changing world. Lauren’s quest had roots 
in a real life event– California Prop 187, which attempted to deny undocumented
immigrants fundamental human rights, before it was deemed unconstitutional. Butler frequently incorporated 
contemporary news into her writing. In her 1998 sequel to "The Parable of the 
Sower," "Parable of the Talents," she wrote of a presidential candidate who controls Americans with virtual 
reality and “shock collars.” His slogan? “Make America great again.” While people have noted her prescience, Butler was also interested in 
re-examining history. For instance,
"Kindred" tells the story of a woman who is repeatedly
pulled back in time to the Maryland plantation 
of her ancestors. Early on, she learns that her mission 
is to save the life of the white man who will rape her great grandmother. If she doesn’t save him, 
she herself will cease to exist. This grim dilemma forces Dana to 
confront the ongoing trauma of slavery and sexual violence 
against Black women. With her stories of women 
founding new societies, time travelers overcoming 
historical strife, and interspecies bonding, Butler had a profound influence on 
the growing popularity of Afrofuturism. That’s a cultural movement where Black writers and artists who are 
inspired by the past, present and future, produce works that incorporate magic, 
history, technology and much more. As Lauren comes to learn in 
"Parable of the Sower," "All that you touch you Change. All that you Change Changes you. The only lasting truth is Change.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What terrible sci-fi movie inspired a young Octavia Butler to ask her mom for a typewriter?
Options: A. Mars Needs Women, B. The Angry Red Planet, C. Devil Girl From Mars, D. The Incredible Shrinking Woman
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the novel by Octavia Butler that tells the story of Lilith Iyapo and her encounter with the Oankali aliens? Options: A. "Parable of the Sower", B. "Dawn", C. "Kindred", D. "Parable of the Talents" Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the main reason why the Oankali aliens want to breed with humans in the novel "Dawn"? Options: A. To create a new species of superhumans, B. To trade DNA and diversify each species' genes, C. To use humans as a food source, D. To study human behavior Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did Octavia Butler's personal experience with a science fiction film influence her writing career? Options: A. It inspired her to write more science fiction stories, B. It discouraged her from pursuing a writing career, C. It motivated her to write better science fiction stories than what she saw in the film, D. It had no impact on her writing career Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the name of the condition that the protagonist Lauren Oya Olamina suffers from in the novel "Parable of the Sower"? Options: A. Hyperempathy, B. Hypersensitivity, C. Empathy disorder, D. Emotional instability Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the main theme of Octavia Butler's novel "Kindred"? Options: A. The struggle for civil rights in the 1960s, B. The trauma of slavery and sexual violence against Black women, C. The power of love and relationships, D. The impact of technology on society Correct Option: B
Question 6: How does Octavia Butler's work relate to the cultural movement of Afrofuturism? Options: A. Her work is a critique of Afrofuturism, B. Her work is an example of Afrofuturism, C. Her work is unrelated to Afrofuturism, D. Her work is a precursor to Afrofuturism Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the name of the presidential candidate in Octavia Butler's novel "Parable of the Talents" who controls Americans with virtual reality and "shock collars"? Options: A. Not specified in the transcript, B. Donald Trump, C. Ronald Reagan, D. George W. Bush Correct Option: A
Question 8: How does Octavia Butler's work often incorporate contemporary news and events? Options: A. She includes news headlines as chapter titles, B. She uses real-life events as inspiration for her stories, C. She includes cameos of real-life figures in her stories, D. She uses news articles as dialogue in her stories Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the central dilemma faced by the protagonist Dana in the novel "Kindred"? Options: A. Whether to save the life of her great-grandmother or not, B. Whether to save the life of the white man who will rape her great-grandmother or not, C. Whether to stay in the present or travel back in time, D. Whether to confront her ancestors or not Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of the phrase "All that you touch you Change. All that you Change Changes you. The only lasting truth is Change" in the context of Octavia Butler's work? Options: A. It highlights the importance of tradition and stability, B. It emphasizes the power of individual agency and control, C. It underscores the idea that change is the only constant in life, D. It suggests that humans are powerless against the forces of change Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 3: How did Octavia Butler's personal experience with a science fiction film influence her writing career? Options: A. It inspired her to write more science fiction stories, B. It discouraged her from pursuing a writing career, C. It motivated her to write better science fiction stories than what she saw in the film, D. It had no impact on her writing career Correct Option: C**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, as both questions are asking about the influence of a science fiction film on Octavia Butler's writing career. The options in Question 3 are also similar to the ground truth MCQ, as they both mention the film's impact on Butler's writing.

However, an even more similar question would be one that directly asks about the title of the film that inspired Butler to ask her mom for a typewriter. Unfortunately, such a question is not present among the generated MCQs.

But among the given options, Question 3 is the most similar.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Following a devastating nuclear war, Lilith Iyapo awakens
after 250 years of stasis to find herself surrounded by a group 
of aliens called the Oankali. These highly evolved beings
want to trade DNA by breeding with humans so that each species’ genes 
can diversify and fortify the other. The only alternative they offer is 
sterilization of the entire human race. Should humanity take the leap into 
the biological unknown, or hold on to its identity and perish? Questions like this haunt 
Octavia Butler’s "Dawn," the first in her trilogy "Lilith’s Brood." A visionary storyteller who 
upended science fiction, Butler built stunning worlds 
throughout her work– and explored dilemmas that keep 
us awake at night. Born in 1947, Butler grew up shy and introverted in 
Pasadena, California. She dreamt up stories from an early age, and was soon scribbling these 
scenarios on paper. At twelve, she begged her mother 
for a typewriter after enduring a campy science fiction
film called "Devil Girl From Mars." Unimpressed with what she saw, Butler knew she could tell a better story. Much science fiction features 
white male heroes who blast aliens or become 
saviors of brown people. Butler wanted to write diverse characters
for diverse audiences. She brought nuance and depth to the 
representation of their experiences. For Butler, imagination was not only for planting 
the seeds of science fiction– but also a strategy for surviving an 
unjust world on one’s own terms. Her work often takes troubling 
features of the world such as discrimination on the basis of 
race, gender, class, or ability, and invites the reader to contemplate 
them in new contexts. One of her most beloved novels, the "Parable of the Sower," follows this pattern. It tells the story of Lauren Oya Olamina as she makes her way through a near-future
California, ruined by corporate greed, inequality, and environmental destruction. As she struggles with hyperempathy, or a condition in the novel that 
causes her to feel others’ pain, and less often, their pleasure. Lauren embarks on a quest with a group 
of refugees to find a place to thrive. There, they seek to live in accordance 
with Lauren’s found religion, Earthseed, which is based on the principle that humans must adapt to an 
ever-changing world. Lauren’s quest had roots 
in a real life event– California Prop 187, which attempted to deny undocumented
immigrants fundamental human rights, before it was deemed unconstitutional. Butler frequently incorporated 
contemporary news into her writing. In her 1998 sequel to "The Parable of the 
Sower," "Parable of the Talents," she wrote of a presidential candidate who controls Americans with virtual 
reality and “shock collars.” His slogan? “Make America great again.” While people have noted her prescience, Butler was also interested in 
re-examining history. For instance,
"Kindred" tells the story of a woman who is repeatedly
pulled back in time to the Maryland plantation 
of her ancestors. Early on, she learns that her mission 
is to save the life of the white man who will rape her great grandmother. If she doesn’t save him, 
she herself will cease to exist. This grim dilemma forces Dana to 
confront the ongoing trauma of slavery and sexual violence 
against Black women. With her stories of women 
founding new societies, time travelers overcoming 
historical strife, and interspecies bonding, Butler had a profound influence on 
the growing popularity of Afrofuturism. That’s a cultural movement where Black writers and artists who are 
inspired by the past, present and future, produce works that incorporate magic, 
history, technology and much more. As Lauren comes to learn in 
"Parable of the Sower," "All that you touch you Change. All that you Change Changes you. The only lasting truth is Change.”

Options: A. hyperempathy, B. emphaticism, C. hypocrisy, D. xenophilia
Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
It’s easy to feel like you’re an even
mix of your parents, but that’s not always the case. So, who should you be blaming over those traits
you don’t like? What did you inherit from Mom and what came
from Dad? Colour-blind? If you’re a male, you can thank your mother. Red-green colour blindness is an X-linked
disorder that affects nearly 6% of the male population worldwide, but only 0.4% of females. This is because males only inherit one X chromosome,
which is from their mother, and that’s where red-green colorblindness comes from. If you’re a female, you have to get a the
X-variant from both parents. So that 0.4% can blame dad as well! Balding? A big component comes from the X-chromosome
here too, so you likely inherited this from your mom. However, a study involving 52,000 people found
that genes on other chromosomes can affect this condition, on top of environmental factors
such as age, stress, and diet - so mom isn’t entirely to blame! Research has also found that the shape of
the end of your nose, the area above and below the lips, cheekbones and the inner corner
of the eye are highly influenced by genetics. And interestingly, the more they resemble
your father as a child, the healthier you’re likely to be. Why? Scientists believe that a father-child resemblance
causes fathers to spend more time engaging in positive parenting, which ultimately contributes
to healthier kids. Now, even though you get half of your 46 chromosomes
from mom and the other from dad, a study involving genetically diverse mice found that for 60%
of genes the paternal copy was more active than the maternal copy. This phenomenon is known as allelic imbalance. The same study also noted that the brains
of these particular mice more closely resembled that of their dad than their mom. However, in humans we actually see the opposite. Our brains are more similar to our mother,
which is particularly true for daughters. Interestingly, the similar brain regions are
actually associated with depressive conditions, suggesting that mood disorders may pass from
mother to daughter. Biologists used to believe that all DNA came
from the nucleus, but we now know that the mitochondria (AKA the powerhouse of the cell)
also kicks in some protein coding genes. And this mitochondrial DNA is specifically
inherited from your mom because your dad’s degraded immediately after fertilization. Considering how important mitochondrial DNA
is in the cell, there is a stronger maternal link. Mutations in mitochondrial DNA have been associated
with Type 2 diabetes and Parkinson’s disease - which more likely came from your mom. Maternal inheritance gave rise to the idea
of a “Mitochondrial Eve”, a woman who lived between 180,000 to 580,000 years ago
from which all human mitochondrial DNA is rooted. At the end of the day, it may seem like a
lot of traits actually come from your mom, or at least, from the X chromosome - and that’s
generally true, genetically. The Y-chromosome is very small, and doesn’t
contain as many genes; and both females and males contain X-chromosomes, which carry more
genes. But as we continue to research more about
ourselves at the genetic level, the division between what you got from mom vs. dad may
become even more pronounced. If you want to know more about your own genetics,
you can visit 23andMe.com/asap, who sponsored this episode. Whether you want to know about your chances
of balding, back hair, your taste sense or where your ancestors came from, 23andMe’s
kit will get you started. We both took it, and I found out the GREAT
news that I’m more prone to having a little upper back hair, which until recently I thought
was FALSE, but as I’ve aged Greg told me is actually TRUE!! What I thought was cool is that you can find
out how certain factors affect your weight. Like for me fast food is likely to have the
biggest impact on my weight followed by exercise. Be sure to head to 23andMe.com/asap for the
latest promotion on your kit. As always, thanks for watching, be sure to
subscribe for more weekly science videos every Thursday, and we will see you next time!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which chromosome do you get most of your traits from?
Options: A. X chromosome, B. Y chromosome
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the male population worldwide is affected by red-green color blindness? Options: A. 0.4%, B. 6%, C. 10%, D. 20% Correct Option: B
Question 2: A study involving genetically diverse mice found that for what percentage of genes was the paternal copy more active than the maternal copy? Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: C
Question 3: Which of the following conditions is associated with mutations in mitochondrial DNA? Options: A. Type 1 diabetes and Alzheimer's disease, B. Type 2 diabetes and Parkinson's disease, C. Type 1 diabetes and Parkinson's disease, D. Type 2 diabetes and Alzheimer's disease Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the term for the phenomenon where the paternal copy of a gene is more active than the maternal copy? Options: A. Allelic balance, B. Allelic imbalance, C. Genetic dominance, D. Genetic recessiveness Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to research, what is the likely outcome for children who resemble their father more closely? Options: A. They are more likely to have health problems, B. They are more likely to have behavioral issues, C. They are more likely to be healthier, D. They are more likely to have learning difficulties Correct Option: C
Question 6: Why do scientists believe that a father-child resemblance contributes to healthier kids? Options: A. Because fathers are more likely to spend time with children who resemble them, B. Because mothers are more likely to spend time with children who resemble their father, C. Because fathers are more likely to engage in positive parenting with children who resemble them, D. Because mothers are more likely to engage in positive parenting with children who resemble their father Correct Option: C
Question 7: If a female is colorblind, what is the likely explanation? Options: A. She inherited the X-variant from her mother, B. She inherited the X-variant from her father, C. She inherited the X-variant from both parents, D. She inherited a mutated gene from her mother Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the name given to the woman from whom all human mitochondrial DNA is thought to be rooted? Options: A. Mitochondrial Eve, B. Genetic Eve, C. Maternal Eve, D. Ancestral Eve Correct Option: A
Question 9: Which of the following is a possible reason why the brains of humans are more similar to their mother's brain, particularly for daughters? Options: A. Because mothers are more likely to engage in positive parenting, B. Because fathers are more likely to engage in positive parenting, C. Because the X-chromosome carries more genes related to brain development, D. Because the similar brain regions are associated with depressive conditions Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the main reason why mitochondrial DNA is specifically inherited from the mother? Options: A. Because the father's mitochondrial DNA is degraded immediately after fertilization, B. Because the mother's mitochondrial DNA is more dominant, C. Because the father's mitochondrial DNA is less important for cell function, D. Because the mother's mitochondrial DNA is more resistant to mutations Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the chromosome from which most traits are inherited. Although there isn't a direct match among the generated MCQs, Question 7 discusses the inheritance of colorblindness, a trait linked to the X-chromosome.
